material.mattext: Which of the following actions will upload user data from a Web form to the receiving server?
Submitting the form
Processing the form
Resetting the form
Storing the form
When creating Web forms, you use the <input> tag to
create text boxes, check boxes, radio buttons, and the Submit and Reset buttons.
create form fields into which the user can enter multiple lines of text.
create single-option and multiple-option lists from which the user can choose items.
create a form into which you can input various form fields.
What occurs when a user clicks the Submit button on a Web form?
The data from all fields in the form is sent to be processed by the action specified in the <form> tag.
All form fields are cleared and the data is submitted.
All form fields are cleared and set back to their default settings.
A Choose File dialog box appears, which the user can use to navigate to and select a local file for uploading.
Radio buttons are reserved for two or more mutually exclusive options on a Web form. How do you ensure this exclusivity?
The radio buttons must share the same name attribute.
The radio buttons must share the same value attribute.
The radio buttons must share the same type attribute.
The radio buttons must share the same checked attribute.
The main advantage of validating data on the client side using JavaScript is that:
you can prevent information from passing to the server until it is correct.
you can save the server resources from having to process the data at all.
you can compel users to submit only truthful information to your server.
you can provide a more dynamic interface to the user for data collection.
What is the main method used by the JavaScript button object?
click()
reset()
submit()
select()
Which example shows the correct generic syntax for the button object?
<input type="button" value="Text on Button" onclick="script to execute" />
<button type="submit" value="Text on Button" click(script to execute) />
<button value="submit" name="Text on Button" onclick="script to execute" />
<input value="button" name="Text on Button" click(script to execute) />
Which of the following demonstrates the proper way to format a string to appear on two lines?
var rhyme = "Hey diddle diddle\nThe cat and the fiddle";
var rhyme = "The cat and the fiddle" var rhyme = "Hey diddle diddle"
var rhyme = "Hey diddle diddle\\nThe cat and the fiddle";

var rhyme = "Hey diddle diddle" +
+ "The cat and the fiddle";

Consider the following text displayed on screen:

Press "enter" to load file
c:\test.txt


Which JavaScript statement will display this?
var getfile="Press \"enter\" to load file\nc:\\test.txt"; alert(getfile);
var getfile='Press \"enter\" to load file\nc:\test.txt'; alert(getfile);
var getfile='Press "enter" to load file\lc:\test.txt'; alert(getfile);
var getfile="Press "enter" to load file\lc:\\test.txt"; alert(getfile);
Which of the following will determine how many characters are in the variable string str?
str.length;
str.length();
length(str);
str.lengthOf;

Consider the following code:

var msg = "A Message";
alert("The position of M in \"" + msg + "\" is " + msg.indexOf("M"));


What will this script display?
It will display: The position of M in "A Message" is 2
It will display: The position of M in "A Message" is -1
It will display: The position of M in "A Message" is 1
It will display: The position of M in "A Message" is 3

Consider the following code:

var myString = "Have a great day!";
var extracted = myString.charAt(myString.length - 1);


What will be assigned to the variable extracted in this code?
The variable extracted will be assigned: !
The variable extracted will be assigned: y
The variable extracted will be assigned: y!
The variable extracted will be assigned: Have a great day

Consider the following code:

var msg = "A Messy Memo";
alert(msg.lastIndexOf("M"));


What will be displayed in the alert box?
The alert will display: 8
The alert will display: Memo
The alert will display: 3
The alert will display: Messy

Consider the following code:

var msg = "A Message";
alert("The extracted text is: " + msg.substring(3, 6));


What will this script display?
It will display: The extracted text is: ess
It will display: The extracted text is: Mes
It will display: The extracted text is: essa
It will display: The extracted text is: Mess

Consider the following variable:

var email = joseph@somehwere.something.com


How can you extract the username portion of the e-mail address in this variable?
email.substring(0, email.indexOf("@"));
email.substring(1, email.indexOf("@") + 1);
email.substring(1, email.indexOf("@"));
email.substring(0, email.indexOf("@") - 1);

Consider the following code:

var myString = "joe@somewhere.com"
alert(myString.substr(4));


What will this code display?
It will display: somewhere.com
It will display: s
It will display: @
It will display: @somewhere.com
You need a three-element array containing the values Larry, Moe and Curly. Which statement will create this array?
var Stooges = ["Larry", "Moe", "Curly"];
var Stooges = ("Larry", "Moe", "Curly");
var Stooges[] = new Array[3]("Larry", "Moe", "Curly");
var Stooges[] = ["Larry", "Moe", "Curly"];

An interface you are developing will display an array in a list format. You want to allow the user to flip the list, making the first item last and the last item first, reversing the order of all items. Which statement will achieve this?
arrayList.reverse();
arrayList.flip();
arrayList = reverse(arrayList);
arrayList = flip(arrayList);
Which statement will reorder and display the array myArray in alphabetical order?
myArray.sort();
myArray.alphabetize();
myArray = sort(myArray);
myArray = alphabetize(myArray);
Which code fragment will create an unordered list using the contents of myArray and display it on the Web page?

var list = "
    "; for (i = 0; i < myArray.length; i++) { list = list + "
  • " + myArray[i] + "
    • "; } list = list + "
"; document.write(list);

var list = "
    "; for (i = 0; i < myArray.length; i++) { list = "
  • " + myArray[i] + "
    • "; } list = "
"; document.write(list);

var list = "
    "; for (i = 1; i < myArray.length() - 1; i++) { list = list + "
  • " + myArray[i] + "
    • "; } list = list + "
"; document.write(list);

var list = "
    "; for (i = 1; i < myArray.length() - 1; i++) { list = "
  • " + myArray[i] + "
    • "; } list = "
"; document.write(list);

Consider the following code fragment:

Year: <input id="byear"/><br/>
Month: <input id="bmonth"/><br/>
Day: <input id="bday"/><br/>
<script type="text/javascript">
var year = document.getElementById("byear").value;
var month = document.getElementById("bmonth").value;
var day = document.getElementById("bday").value;
// Insert code here
</script>


Given this script, which code will record the user's birth date?
var bday = new Date(); bday.setYear(year); bday.setMonth(month - 1); bday.setDate(day);
var bday = new Date(); setYear(bday, year); setMonth(bday, month); setDay(bday, day);
bday.setYear(year); bday.setMonth(month - 1); bday.setDate(day);
var bday = new Date(); bday.Year = year; bday.Month = month; bday.Day = day;

A new Date object has been assigned to a variable using the following statement:

var myDate = new Date();


What will be the initial value of the variable?
The current date and time
No value yet, the variable must be initialized first
Incorrect assignment, the Date function requires a parameter
January 1, 1970 12:00 AM GMT

Consider the following code:

var season = 5;
var seasonName = "Summer";
switch (season) {
case(1):
seasonName = "Winter";
break;
case(2):
seasonName = "Spring";
break;
case(3):
seasonName = "Summer";
break;
case(4):
seasonName = "Fall";
break;
default:
seasonName = "Unknown";
}


What is the value of seasonName after execution?
Unknown
Summer
Winter
Spring
Which of the following accurately describes the purpose of the innerHTML property?
It allows you to manipulate specified elements in a script by setting and retrieving their contents.
It allows you to access all elements in a script with a specified name value or tag name, and return them in an array.
It allows you to access all elements in a script with a specified id value and return them in an array.
It allows you to access all the properties of the first occurrence of an element in a script with a specified id value.
Which of the following methods will access all occurrences in the page of an element with a specified name value and return them in an array?
getElementsByName
getElementsByTagName
getElementById
innerHTML
Which method retrieves the corresponding value of an attribute?
getAttribute
setAttribute
removeAttribute
innerHTML
Which method dynamically modifies the value of an element's attribute?
setAttribute
getAttribute
removeAttribute
getElementById

Consider the following HTML page code:

<html>
<head>
<script type="text/javascript">
function addbutton()
{
var md = document.getElementById("mydiv");
var newtext = document.createTextNode("Clicked");
var appendedText = md.appendChild(newtext);
}
</script>
</head>
<body>
<p>Beginning</p>
<div id="mydiv">
<p><input type="button" onclick="addbutton()" name="button1" value="Add" /> </p>
</div>
<p>Bottom</p>
</body>
</html>


What happens when the button on this page is clicked?
The text "Clicked" is added to the end of the div area called mydiv.
The text "Clicked" is added to the page before the Beginning paragraph.
The text "Clicked" is added to the page after the Bottom paragraph.
The text on the page is replaced with the text "Clicked".
